name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions:

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment.
  2. After selecting these indices, you then replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no operations are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        operations = []
        # We will perform at most n operations, as allowed by the problem statement.
        for i in range(n - 1):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i + min(range(n - i), key=array.__getitem__)
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                operations.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, min_index - i))
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array[i:min_index + 1] = array[i + 1:min_index + 1] + array[i:i + 1]

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # Implementing a strategy to sort using cyclic shifts
        # This strategy attempts to sort the array by identifying unsorted segments
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[i] > array[j]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to sort the segment
                    l = i + 1
                    r = j + 1
                    d = 1
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    array[l-1:r] = array[l-1+d:r] + array[l-1:l-1+d]
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implementing a simple strategy to sort using cyclic shifts
        # This is not optimized but meets the requirement of using no more than n shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array != sorted(array):
            # Simple strategy: perform a cyclic shift on the entire array
            # This is a naive approach and can be optimized
            for i in range(n - 1):
                if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment from i+1 to n
                    l = i + 1
                    r = n
                    d = 1
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    if array == sorted(array):
                        break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts.
        # This is not necessarily optimal but will ensure the array is sorted within n shifts.
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if array[i] > array[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part of the array
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                if min_index != i + 1:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    d = min_index - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[i:min_index + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
                    # Record the action
                    actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing an integer n and an array of integers.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations k and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implementing a simple cyclic shift sorting algorithm
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1

                # Perform cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if sorted
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = array.index(sorted_array[i], i)
                # Perform a cyclic shift to place the element in the correct position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = array[i:correct_pos + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = shifted_segment
                    # Record the action
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()

    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        array = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
        index += 2

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d) indicating the segment and the offset.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                segment = deque(array[l-1:r])
                segment.rotate(-d)
                array[l-1:r] = list(segment)
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    array = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, array))

# Output interface
results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    k, actions = result
    print(k)
    for action in actions:
        print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break

            # Find the end of the unsorted segment
            for r in range(l + 1, n):
                if array[r] < array[r - 1]:
                    break

            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
            d = 1  # We can choose any offset, here we choose 1 for simplicity
            segment = array[l:r+1]
            shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
            array[l:r+1] = shifted_segment
            actions.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within the constraints provided.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i:] != sorted_array[i:]:
                # Find the first unsorted segment
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if array[j] < array[i]:
                        # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
                        l, r = i + 1, j + 1
                        d = 1
                        segment = array[l-1:r]
                        shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                        array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                        actions.append((l, r, d))
                        break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing a series of cyclic shifts. The number of shifts should not exceed the length of the array, and any valid sequence of shifts that results in a sorted array is acceptable.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts': The number of cyclic shifts performed should be less than or equal to the length of the array.
    Implementation: Ensure that the count of cyclic shifts does not exceed n.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary': Refers to any valid choice within given constraints, such as selecting any valid indices for l and r.
    Implementation: Use loops or conditions to explore different valid segments for shifting.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If so, output k = 0.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be shifted to bring the array closer to a sorted state.
4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments and keep track of the operations.
5. Ensure that the number of operations does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of operations and their details for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with minimum length array:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
            1 2 1
    Explanation: A single shift is needed to sort the array.

    Test case with all identical elements:

    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are identical.

    6. Keep track of the number of shifts and ensure it does not exceed 'n'.
    7. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift.

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of an array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within the segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort the array'
    Explanation: The goal is to rearrange the elements of the array in non-decreasing order using cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that for an array of length n, you can perform up to n shifts.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array itself.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output 0 and no actions.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be shifted to move elements closer to their correct positions.
4. Use a loop to perform up to n cyclic shifts:
   - Identify a segment (l, r) that can be shifted.
   - Determine the offset d for the left shift.
   - Perform the cyclic shift and update the array.
   - Record the action (l, r, d).
5. After sorting, output the number of actions and the list of actions for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case 1: [1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case 2: [3, 3, 3] = 0
    Explanation: All elements are identical, so the array is already sorted.

    Test case 3: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 5
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order, requiring multiple shifts to sort.

# [extra code for edge case]

We will implement a function that sorts the array using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve identifying segments that can be shifted to bring the array closer to a sorted state. We will use a simple logic to ensure the number of shifts does not exceed the array length. The implementation will handle multiple test cases efficiently and provide output in the required format.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This can be implemented by keeping a counter for the number of shifts and ensuring it does not surpass n.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, read the array and its length.
    2. Check if the array is already sorted; if so, output 0 shifts.
    3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be shifted to bring elements closer to their sorted positions.
    4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, keeping track of the number of shifts.
    5. Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    6. Output the number of shifts and their details in the required format.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: [5, 5, 5, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is trivially sorted as all elements are identical.

    Test case with minimum length:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift is needed to sort the array.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic already considers arrays that are sorted or have identical elements by checking if sorting is needed before performing any shifts.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
